reasoning:
The critique targets the paper’s Section 3.2 move from (approximate) linearity in resources to the claim that mostly-great futures are a very narrow target because there is effectively a uniquely value-efficient use of resources. That step is one pillar in the broader “views are fussy / no easy eutopia” case, but not the only one (the essay also leans on historical/moral-catastrophe examples, the multiplicative-fragility model in §2, and the bounded-view analysis in §3.3), so centrality is moderate rather than decisive.

On strength: the critique plausibly notes under-specification (no explicit model of admissible policies/resource decomposition) and raises a live possibility (degeneracy/broad basins of near-optimality) that would weaken the inference from linearity to extreme specificity. However, it mostly argues from “not formally specified” and from an analogy to institutionally entangled examples, without directly engaging the paper’s key additional premise driving narrowness on linear views—fat-tailed value-efficiency and the claim that near-max efficiency configurations are rare. It therefore weakens the argument somewhat but does not come close to refuting it.

Relevance is moderate: it engages a Tier-2-ish component of Forethought’s better-futures framework (narrow-target/eutopian difficulty) and could inform how they formalize/defend the linear-view case, but it does not directly address a Tier 3 live disagreement or offer a concrete alternative model that would shift their agenda.
title: The critique fails to establish that linear value theories require narrowly defined resource allocations
